## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 327, 360, 343]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 370, 418, 385]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 392, 459, 407]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 390, 434]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 785, 463]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 464, 320, 477]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 479, 504, 493]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 504, 508]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 509, 380, 523]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 538, 907, 567]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 568, 907, 597]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 598, 600, 612]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 613, 606, 627]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 642, 608, 657]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 658, 755, 673]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 674, 440, 688]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 77, 96, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 670, 97]]<|/det|>
Showing all necessary working, solve the equation \(4x - 11x^{\frac{1}{2}} + 6 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 77, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
A line has equation \(y = x + 1\) and a curve has equation \(y = x^{2} + bx + 5\). Find the set of values of the constant \(b\) for which the line meets the curve. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 267, 918, 319]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a triangle \(OAB\) in which angle \(ABO\) is a right angle, angle \(AOB = \frac{1}{2}\pi\) radians and \(AB = 5 \text{ cm}\). The arc \(BC\) is part of a circle with centre \(A\) and meets \(OA\) at \(C\). The arc \(CD\) is part of a circle with centre \(O\) and meets \(OB\) at \(D\). Find the area of the shaded region. [8]

A curve has equation \(y = \frac{1}{2} (4x - 3)^{-1}\). The point \(A\) on the curve has coordinates \(\left(1, \frac{1}{2}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 107, 154, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 107, 185, 125]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 107, 645, 125]]<|/det|>

Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the point where this normal meets the curve again. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 511, 154, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 511, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
A point is moving along the curve in such a way that as it passes through \(A\) its \(x\)-coordinate is decreasing at the rate of 0.3 units per second. Find the rate of change of its \(y\)-coordinate at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 543, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 574, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 75, 853, 92]]<|/det|>
The one-one function f is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = (x - 3)^2 - 1\) for \(x < a\), where \(a\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 100, 195, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 100, 494, 117]]<|/det|>
State the greatest possible value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 918, 117]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 128, 918, 218]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 235, 193, 253]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 235, 918, 268]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(a\) takes this greatest possible value. State the range of f and find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 252, 918, 269]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 280, 918, 922]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 149, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 75, 585, 92]]<|/det|>
The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}(x) = (x - 3)^2\) for \(x \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 101, 195, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 101, 918, 134]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{gg}(2x)\) can be expressed in the form \((2x - 3)^4 + b(2x - 3)^2 + c\), where \(b\) and \(c\) are constants to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 115, 918, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 349, 193, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 349, 672, 368]]<|/det|>
Hence expand \(\mathrm{gg}(2x)\) completely, simplifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 349, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
